Complete Guide to Mexico's Cenotes

Swimming in Sacred Mayan Waters

Last updated: January 2025

Cenotes are natural sinkholes filled with crystal-clear freshwater, formed when limestone bedrock collapses and reveals underground rivers. The Yucatán Peninsula has an estimated 6,000+ cenotes, and they were sacred to the ancient Maya—portals to the underworld. Today they offer some of the world's most unique swimming, snorkeling, and diving experiences.

In This Guide

  • What Are Cenotes?
  • Best Cenotes Near Tulum
  • Best Cenotes Near Valladolid
  • Best Cenotes Near Playa del Carmen
  • Hidden & Lesser-Known Cenotes
  • Cenote Diving Guide
  • Cenote Snorkeling Tips
  • Visiting Cenotes Responsibly
  • Practical Tips for Visiting
  • Cenote Photo Tips

What Are Cenotes?

{<strong>Geology:</strong> Cenotes formed over millions of years as rainwater dissolved the limestone bedrock of the Yucatán Peninsula. The result is an interconnected underground river system spanning hundreds of miles, with cenotes as natural access points to these subterranean waters.</p><p><strong>Types of Cenotes:</strong></p><p>1. <strong>Open/Cave Cenotes (Abiertos):</strong> Fully collapsed ceiling, open to the sky. Example: Cenote Azul</p><p>2. <strong>Semi-open Cenotes:</strong> Partially collapsed ceiling with some cave overhang. Example: Ik Kil</p><p>3. <strong>Cave Cenotes (Cavernas):</strong> Mostly underground with small opening. Example: Cenote Suytun</p><p>4. <strong>Underground Cenotes:</strong> Fully enclosed, accessed through cave entrances. Example: Cenotes at Aktun Chen</p><p><strong>Why They're Special:</strong></p><ul><li>Visibility often exceeds 100 feet (30+ meters)</p><ul><li>Constant temperature around 75-77°F (24-25°C) year-round</p><ul><li>Unique ecosystems with endemic species</p><ul><li>Haloclines create visual effects where fresh and salt water meet</p><ul><li>Stalactites and stalagmites in cave cenotes</p><ul><li>Sacred significance to Mayan culture}

Best Cenotes Near Tulum

{<strong>Gran Cenote</strong></p><ul><li>Type: Semi-open with cave sections</p><ul><li>Best for: Swimming, snorkeling, beginners</p><ul><li>Highlights: Turtles, clear water, easy access</p><ul><li>Price: ~$180 MXN</p><ul><li>Tip: Arrive at 8am opening to beat crowds</p><p><strong>Cenote Calavera (Temple of Doom)</strong></p><ul><li>Type: Open pit with jumping platforms</p><ul><li>Best for: Cliff jumping, photography</p><ul><li>Highlights: Skull-like appearance from above, 3 holes to jump through</p><ul><li>Price: ~$150 MXN</p><ul><li>Tip: Ladders provided; not for claustrophobic visitors</p><p><strong>Casa Cenote</strong></p><ul><li>Type: Open-air, mangrove-lined</p><ul><li>Best for: Snorkeling, families, relaxed swimming</p><ul><li>Highlights: Possible manatee sightings, connects to ocean</p><ul><li>Price: ~$150 MXN</p><ul><li>Tip: Brings mask/snorkel for fish watching in mangroves</p><p><strong>Cenote Cristal & Cenote Escondido</strong></p><ul><li>Type: Open, lake-like</p><ul><li>Best for: Swimming, relaxing</p><ul><li>Highlights: Platforms and swings, less crowded, beautiful setting</p><ul><li>Price: ~$150 MXN (both)</p><ul><li>Tip: Visit both—they're across the road from each other</p><p><strong>Cenote Dos Ojos</strong></p><ul><li>Type: Cave/cavern system</p><ul><li>Best for: Diving, advanced snorkeling</p><ul><li>Highlights: Two connected cenotes, incredible formations, bat cave</p><ul><li>Price: ~$350 MXN</p><ul><li>Tip: Book a cavern dive for the full experience}

Best Cenotes Near Valladolid

{<strong>Cenote Ik Kil</strong></p><ul><li>Type: Open pit with cascading vines</p><ul><li>Best for: Iconic photos, swimming</p><ul><li>Highlights: 85-foot drop, hanging roots, restaurant</p><ul><li>Price: ~$150 MXN</p><ul><li>Tip: Visit after Chichén Itzá, arrive after 2pm when tours leave</p><p><strong>Cenote Suytun</strong></p><ul><li>Type: Cave cenote with light beam</p><ul><li>Best for: Photography, unique experience</p><ul><li>Highlights: Single beam of light on platform—iconic Instagram shot</p><ul><li>Price: ~$150 MXN</p><ul><li>Tip: Morning offers best light beam. Platform gets crowded—patience needed</p><p><strong>Cenote Oxman</strong></p><ul><li>Type: Open with rope swing</p><ul><li>Best for: Adventure seekers, families</p><ul><li>Highlights: Giant rope swing, buffet restaurant</p><ul><li>Price: ~$200 MXN (includes buffet)</p><ul><li>Tip: Great for a half-day with lunch included</p><p><strong>Cenote Zací</strong></p><ul><li>Type: Open/semi-cave, in town</p><ul><li>Best for: Convenient quick swim</p><ul><li>Highlights: Located in Valladolid downtown, easy access</p><ul><li>Price: ~$50 MXN</p><ul><li>Tip: Combine with colonial town exploration</p><p><strong>Cenote Samula & X'keken</strong></p><ul><li>Type: Cave cenotes</p><ul><li>Best for: Dramatic cave experience</p><ul><li>Highlights: Tree roots reaching to water, cathedral-like caves</p><ul><li>Price: ~$150 MXN (both)</p><ul><li>Tip: Visit both; they're in the same complex}

Best Cenotes Near Playa del Carmen

{<strong>Cenote Azul</strong></p><ul><li>Type: Open, multiple pools</p><ul><li>Best for: Families, beginners, cliff jumping</p><ul><li>Highlights: Various depth pools, platforms, on-site restaurant</p><ul><li>Price: ~$120 MXN</p><ul><li>Tip: Great for groups with mixed abilities</p><p><strong>Cenote Jardin del Eden (Ponderosa)</strong></p><ul><li>Type: Large open cenote</p><ul><li>Best for: Diving, snorkeling</p><ul><li>Highlights: Huge cenote, good for training dives, fish</p><ul><li>Price: ~$200 MXN</p><ul><li>Tip: Popular with divers; book dive shops in PDC</p><p><strong>Cenote Tajma Ha</strong></p><ul><li>Type: Underground cave system</p><ul><li>Best for: Certified divers only</p><ul><li>Highlights: Sugar bowl cave formations, halocline effects</p><ul><li>Price: Dive tours ~$100-150 USD</p><ul><li>Tip: One of the world's best cave dives—requires certification</p><p><strong>Cenote Chaak Tun</strong></p><ul><li>Type: Cave system</p><ul><li>Best for: Cave exploration, adventure</p><ul><li>Highlights: Guided tours through caves, rappelling options</p><ul><li>Price: ~$700 MXN (guided tour)</p><ul><li>Tip: Great for those who want adventure without diving}

Hidden & Lesser-Known Cenotes

{<strong>Cenote Yaxbacaltun</strong></p><ul><li>Location: South of Tulum</p><ul><li>Why visit: Almost no tourists, authentic experience</p><ul><li>Access: Rough road, ask locals for directions</p><ul><li>Price: Small donation to community</p><p><strong>Cenote Xcanahaltun</strong></p><ul><li>Location: Near Homún (cenotes ring)</p><ul><li>Why visit: Private cenote experiences, local guides</p><ul><li>Access: Book through Homún community tours</p><ul><li>Price: ~$100-200 MXN</p><p><strong>Cenote Dzonbakal</strong></p><ul><li>Location: Near Cuzamá</p><ul><li>Why visit: Arrive by horse-drawn cart (coche)</p><ul><li>Access: Local tour required</p><ul><li>Price: ~$400 MXN (includes 3 cenotes)</p><p><strong>Cenote Noh Mozón</strong></p><ul><li>Location: Near Pixya</p><ul><li>Why visit: Spectacular light effects, truly hidden</p><ul><li>Access: Very rough road, local guide recommended</p><ul><li>Price: Small community donation</p><p><strong>Santa Barbara Cenotes</strong></p><ul><li>Location: Near Homún</p><ul><li>Why visit: Three cenotes in pristine jungle, community-run</p><ul><li>Access: Book through community</p><ul><li>Price: ~$450 MXN</p><p><strong>Pro Tip:</strong> Hiring a local driver/guide to explore off-the-beaten-path cenotes is the best way to have authentic experiences without crowds.}

Cenote Diving Guide

{<strong>Why Dive Cenotes?</strong> Yucatán cenote diving is bucket-list worthy. Crystal visibility (100+ feet), otherworldly light effects, massive stalactites, halocline shimmer, and connection to the world's longest underwater cave systems.</p><p><strong>Types of Diving:</strong></p><p>1. <strong>Cavern Diving:</strong> Stay within natural light zone, max 130ft from exit. Open Water certified divers can do this with a cavern guide.</p><p>2. <strong>Cave Diving:</strong> Venture beyond natural light into full darkness. Requires specific cave diving certification (Technical Diving International or similar).</p><p><strong>Best Cenotes for Diving:</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Dos Ojos:</strong> Most popular, excellent for all levels</p><ul><li><strong>The Pit:</strong> Deep (400+ feet), dramatic light, advanced</p><ul><li><strong>Angelita:</strong> Underwater 'island' at 100ft, halocline cloud</p><ul><li><strong>Dreamgate:</strong> Spectacular formations, experienced divers</p><ul><li><strong>Carwash (Aktun Ha):</strong> Good for training, fish, turtles</p><p><strong>Requirements:</strong></p><ul><li>Open Water certification (minimum for cavern)</p><ul><li>Good buoyancy control</p><ul><li>No touch policy (formations are fragile)</p><ul><li>Certified guide required for all cenote dives</p><p><strong>Costs:</strong></p><ul><li>2-tank cavern dive: $100-160 USD</p><ul><li>Cave diving intro course: $300-500 USD</p><ul><li>Full cave certification: $1,500-3,000 USD</p><p><strong>Recommended Dive Shops:</strong></p><ul><li>Koox Diving (Playa del Carmen)</p><ul><li>Dive Cenotes Mexico (Tulum)</p><ul><li>Hidden Worlds (Akumal)</p><ul><li>Pro Dive Mexico (Playa/Cozumel)}

Cenote Snorkeling Tips

{<strong>What to Expect:</strong> Snorkeling cenotes is magical. The water is so clear you'll feel like you're floating in air. Most cenotes have platforms, stairs, or ladders for easy access.</p><p><strong>Best Cenotes for Snorkeling:</strong></p><ol><li>Gran Cenote - Turtles, caves you can swim into, platforms</p><ol><li>Casa Cenote - Fish in mangroves, possible manatees</p><ol><li>Cenote Cristal - Easy swimming, beautiful</p><ol><li>Cenote Azul - Multiple pools, fish</p><ol><li>Dos Ojos - If you want to see cave formations from surface</p><p><strong>Gear:</strong></p><ul><li>Bring your own mask and snorkel for best fit</p><ul><li>Rentals available at most cenotes (~$50-100 MXN)</p><ul><li>Life jackets required at some cenotes</p><ul><li>Water shoes helpful for rocky entries</p><p><strong>Tips:</strong></p><ul><li>Shower before entering (removes sunscreen oils)</p><ul><li>Don't touch formations or walls</p><ul><li>Watch for depth changes—some areas are very deep</p><ul><li>Stay calm near cave openings—disorientation possible</p><ul><li>Morning visits have better light penetration</p><p><strong>Non-Swimmers:</strong> Many cenotes are fine for non-swimmers with life jackets. Float and enjoy—no swimming needed. Cenotes like Ik Kil and Suytun have shallow areas and platforms.}

Visiting Cenotes Responsibly

{<strong>Environmental Rules:</strong></p><p>1. <strong>Sunscreen:</strong> Use ONLY reef-safe, biodegradable sunscreen or none at all. Chemicals damage ecosystems and cloud the water. Many cenotes ban regular sunscreen.</p><p>2. <strong>Shower First:</strong> Rinse off oils, sweat, and sunscreen before entering. Showers provided.</p><p>3. <strong>No Touching:</strong> Don't touch stalactites, stalagmites, or walls. Formations took thousands of years to form; oils from hands damage them.</p><p>4. <strong>No Littering:</strong> Pack out everything. Cenotes connect to the ocean—pollution spreads.</p><p>5. <strong>No Feeding Fish:</strong> Disrupts natural behavior and ecosystem.</p><p>6. <strong>Respect Wildlife:</strong> Turtles, fish, and other creatures live here. Don't chase or touch them.</p><p><strong>Cultural Respect:</strong></p><ul><li>Cenotes were sacred to the Maya—treat them with reverence</p><ul><li>Some cenotes are on community land—support local management</p><ul><li>Ask permission before photographing locals or ceremonies</p><ul><li>Pay fair prices—tourism supports communities</p><p><strong>Sustainable Choices:</strong></p><ul><li>Visit lesser-known cenotes to reduce pressure on popular ones</p><ul><li>Book community-run cenotes (Homún, Cuzamá)</p><ul><li>Hire local guides rather than big tour operators</p><ul><li>Visit during off-peak hours}

Practical Tips for Visiting

{<strong>When to Go:</strong></p><ul><li>Early morning (8-10am): Best light, fewest crowds</p><ul><li>Late afternoon (3-5pm): Tour groups gone, golden light</p><ul><li>Avoid: 11am-2pm when crowds peak</p><ul><li>Rainy season: Water can be cloudier but fewer tourists</p><p><strong>What to Bring:</strong></p><ul><li>Swimsuit (wear it under clothes)</p><ul><li>Towel (microfiber dries fast)</p><ul><li>Water shoes or sandals with grip</p><ul><li>Waterproof camera/GoPro</p><ul><li>Cash in pesos (most don't take cards)</p><ul><li>Water and snacks</p><ul><li>Reef-safe sunscreen or UV protective clothing</p><ul><li>Dry bag for electronics</p><p><strong>What to Expect:</strong></p><ul><li>Entrance fees: $100-500 MXN per cenote</p><ul><li>Facilities: Basic at most (bathrooms, showers, lockers for fee)</p><ul><li>Food: Some have restaurants; many don't</p><ul><li>Rental gear: Masks, snorkels, life jackets available</p><ul><li>Guides: Optional at most; required at some</p><p><strong>Getting There:</strong></p><ul><li>Rental car offers most flexibility</p><ul><li>Colectivos (shared vans) run main routes</p><ul><li>Tours include transport but limit time</p><ul><li>Uber works in Tulum/PDC but may not go to remote cenotes</p><p><strong>Multi-Cenote Days:</strong> Many cenotes cluster together, making it easy to visit 2-4 in a day. Group tickets sometimes available. Pace yourself—it's more tiring than it seems!}

Cenote Photo Tips

{<strong>Above Water:</strong></p><ul><li>Visit during midday for best light beams (cave cenotes)</p><ul><li>Morning/late afternoon for open cenotes</p><ul><li>Arrive early to get platform shots without crowds</p><ul><li>Wide angle lens captures scale</p><ul><li>Bring waterproof camera or housing</p><p><strong>Underwater:</strong></p><ul><li>GoPro works great in cenotes (clear water, good light)</p><ul><li>Point toward light source for dramatic shots</p><ul><li>Shoot in RAW if possible</p><ul><li>Swim slowly to avoid stirring sediment</p><ul><li>Natural light is sufficient—flash optional</p><p><strong>Instagram Spots:</strong></p><ul><li>Cenote Suytun: Light beam on platform</p><ul><li>Ik Kil: Vines cascading down</p><ul><li>Gran Cenote: Turtle encounters</p><ul><li>Cenote Calavera: Skull-shaped light</p><ul><li>Dos Ojos: Cave formations</p><p><strong>Drone Rules:</strong></p><ul><li>Drones prohibited at most cenotes</p><ul><li>Always ask permission</p><ul><li>Private cenotes may allow with negotiation</p><ul><li>Be respectful of other visitors</p><p><strong>Pro Tips:</strong></p><ul><li>Bring lens wipes (humidity is high)</p><ul><li>Use burst mode for action shots</p><ul><li>Get underwater early before crowds cloud water</p><ul><li>Model shots: Have someone swim in light beam}

Frequently Asked Questions

Are cenotes safe to swim in?

Yes, cenotes are generally safe for swimming. The water is clean freshwater, and most popular cenotes have proper safety measures including life jackets, platforms, and staff. However, be aware of depth (some areas are very deep), respect any posted rules, wear life jackets if you're not a strong swimmer, and never dive or enter caves without proper certification and guides. Some cenotes have hidden depth changes or currents.

Do I need to know how to swim to visit cenotes?

No, many cenotes are accessible to non-swimmers. Life jackets are available (often required) at most cenotes, allowing you to float comfortably. Cenotes like Ik Kil, Suytun, and many others have shallow areas, platforms, and stairs. You can enjoy the experience simply by floating or wading. Choose open cenotes with good facilities for the easiest experience.

What is reef-safe sunscreen and where can I buy it?

Reef-safe sunscreen is biodegradable and free of oxybenzone and octinoxate—chemicals that damage marine ecosystems. Look for brands with zinc oxide or titanium dioxide as active ingredients. Available at Walmart, pharmacies, and eco-shops in Tulum and Playa del Carmen. Better yet, wear UV protective clothing and skip sunscreen entirely when visiting cenotes. Many cenotes will turn you away if you have visible sunscreen on.

How much time do I need at each cenote?

Plan 1-2 hours per cenote for a relaxed experience. Quick swimmers might do 45 minutes. Photographers, divers, and those who want to soak it all in should allow 2+ hours. If visiting multiple cenotes in a day, 3-4 is a comfortable maximum before fatigue sets in. Remember that getting to and from cenotes takes time too.

Can I visit cenotes during rainy season?

Yes, cenotes are a great rainy season activity since they're mostly sheltered. However, heavy rains can temporarily cloud the water with runoff. Cave cenotes are less affected than open ones. The advantage is far fewer tourists during rainy season (June-October). After a few dry days, water clarity usually returns. Rainy season afternoons often bring brief storms, so mornings are best.
